title: July Ordinances
text:
July Ordinances, also known as the Four Ordinances of Saint-Cloud, were a series of decrees set forth by <a href="Charles%20X%20of%20France">Charles X</a> and <a href="Jules%20Armand%20de%20Polignac">Jules Armand de Polignac</a>, the chief minister, in July 1830. 
Compelled by what he felt to be a growing, manipulative radicalism in the elected government, Charles felt that as <a href="king">king</a> by right of birth, his primary duty was the guarantee of order and <a href="happiness">happiness</a> in <a href="France">France</a> and its people; not in political bipartisanship and the self-interpreted rights of implacable political enemies. 
The result was that on 9 July 1830, Charles announced that in his interpretation of, and in full compliance with, Article 14 of the <a href="Charter%20of%201814">Charter of 1814</a>, he would henceforth govern by "ordonnances". On 25 July, while a guest at Saint-Cloud, he signed the infamous "July Ordinances" which were published in the Parisian newspaper "Moniteur" the following day. 
The ordinances of 26 July:
It was intended to quell the people of <a href="France">France</a>. However, the ordinances had the opposite effect of angering the <a href="France">French</a> citizens. Journalists gathered in protest at the headquarters of the "<a href="Le%20National%20%28newspaper%29">National</a>" daily, founded in January 1830 by <a href="Adolphe%20Thiers">Adolphe Thiers</a>, <a href="Armand%20Carrel">Armand Carrel</a>, and others. The final result was the <a href="July%20Revolution">July Revolution</a> and Charles X's <a href="abdication">abdication</a> and exile.
